newsitem.title: INDIA: India rupee ends steady v dlr after early RBI bid.
newsitem.headline: India rupee ends steady v dlr after early RBI bid.

text.p: The rupee ended steady at 35.705/710 against the dollar after the market forced an early intervention by the central bank to halt the rupee's rise above the 35.70-mark, dealers said.
"People were caught long yesterday," said a dealer. "Everyone had expected the RBI (Reserve Bank of India) to come in earlier -- we could not sell enough as RBI came in late."
The State Bank of India (SBI), India's leading bank, was in a buying mood, absorbing sizeable amounts of dollars at 35.700. Some leading foreign banks were sellers, dealers said.
Earlier this week, the RBI bought in the last half-hour of trading sessions, which enabled it to reverse the rising rupee tide without large purchases, dealers said.
On Wednesday, the RBI was forced to intervene before 1500 hours local (0930 GMT), buying over $60 million, dealers said.
After RBI struck, SBI stepped up its bids to 35.71 from 35.70 rupees earlier, absorbing lots of supplies, dealers said.
SBI later brought down its bids to end the day at the closing rate of 35.70/71, they said.
One dealer said the RBI's purchase price showed a downtrend, which did not augur well for market participants. RBI's dollar purchase price fell to 35.71 on Wednesday from 35.73 on Monday.
On Monday and Tuesday, RBI stepped in after the rupee breached the 35.70 mark, but on Wednesday, it pre-empted the crash through its early intervention, dealers said.
The six-month annualised forward premium closed Wednesday at 3.53 percent, little changed from the previous 3.52 percent.
